comments.commentBody:
We're talking about towns whose teams should be in AAA or AAAA. Ask yourselves: why should 10 milllion or so people in the NY area support a baseball team in Milwaukee? Should New Yorkers pay at the turnstiles so that the best players can be drafted by Milwaukee (they'll always get the first draft picks), and retained by Milwaukee? Do New Yorkers want to see great ball players, or do the want Milwaukeeans to see them?

Hey Milwaukee, if you don't like being in the majors, demote yourself already. And if you're thinking we'll miss you, don't worry, we won't. We really don't need you in the major leagues, surprise to say. We've got way more than enough teams already, and an oversaturated market. Get into the minor leagues and feel good about yourselves or, be happy that you get a chance to see the Yankees or Mets from time to time.

You can't have it both ways. You want the benefits of living in the big city, and get big city entertainment, while you enjoy the benefits of living in a smaller city?

Ladies and gentlemen please welcome the war! I was actually more disturbed by the cynic comments between the Apache crew than by the dramatic images of the killing. Probably watching that video without the audio and transcription the emotional impact would be almost unrealistic. I don't intend to justify the chopper crew but I think that there is no difference between that attack and any other, for example, high altitude bombing mission. In many cases the killing of other human being is something of abstract. During the war the soldiers are in a "revenge mode", something nobody can stop. It's pure craziness with a domino effect starting from who signs the declaration of war. About WikiLeaks I believe that it's a form of journalism at full throttle but sometime its uncontrolled power can hurt.

While there is global outrage on how cold-bloodedly Americans can murder Arabs, we see the NY Times (Cohen and Stelter) obfuscate by focussing predictably on an irrelevance...

"The site is not shy about its intent to shape media coverage... WikiLeaks did not merely post the 38-minute video, it used the label “Collateral Murder” and said it depicted “indiscriminate” and “unprovoked” killing."

Ah, so the real evil here is in the wrong labeling.

The video shows war at its worse. I can understand going after armed militants. I can understand using helicopters to id them. I can understand using force because they were armed. I can understand mistaking a reporter and his driver. What I can't understand is the second round. Since when to we shoot the wounded? Why do we have to shoot good samaritans, even though they might be on the side of the enemy? What happened to those two children? Listening to the dialog,
I am disturbed by the interchange. Was I listening to kids playing a violent video game? Time to end the Iraq war before it totally corrupts our young people.

I think organizations such as WikiLeaks provide an invaluable service, since others seem either unwilling or unable to track down the real story on these important issues. The so-called mainstream media really won't pursue anything controversial, in spite of characterizations by the Right. Would the MSM even consider investigating things similar to Watergate or the Pentagon Papers in this era? Do they have the resources?

Yes, WikiLeaks is a threat to (misdeeds in) the military. Thank God!
President Barack Obama is finally growing up in his role as the President of the United States.  Thank God for that.

Nowhere was any evidence brought up in this article, just accusations.  So, no matter how heinous the alleged crime, it's execution without trial, pure Nazism.  The Founding Fathers would puke all over Dennis Blair, and Barack Obama too for that matter.

The US military has been and is acting in Iraq and Afghanistan in the name of every US citizen.

It is us that are shooting these bullets at the journalists, innocent men and children, and cheering when people are hit and life struck from them.

The audio was the most disturbing [art...even if these men were insurgents, the cheering at murder is insensitive and macabre. Even if they were insurgents, the soldier's eagerness to shoot a wounded man being moved into a van??? Is this not against the Geneva Convention?

The soldier's banter sounded like that of teenagers playing a video game, rather than soldiers snuffing out life. Cheering at each death.

We should be watching these videos every day the war continues...as as long as we can continue to watch such murders, then shall we continue to engage in wars. If we can't stomach this, we need to leave. And I personally, can't stomach this senseless, insensitive murdering.

The soldiers are killing in our name. Let's open our eyes, bear witness, own it and make our choice as a nation to fight or not to fight. But most of all, let's not fight with our heads in the sand.

Thank you Wikileaks. Keep it coming. I believe in what they are doing. I just donated so they can continue to shed the light.
About time this President grows a backbone. The liberal drones who inhabit an alternate universe where facts and reality never enter into the equation will, of course, have their usual fits.

Obama is on the right track here, but please,in keeping with the president's new policy on the use of nuclear energy, no nukes here since Yemen has no nukes and the target only sent in a guy with conventional explosives in his underwear.  But do remember, send Anwar al-Awlaki an email with his Miranda rights spelled out before the instrument of termination is released.  And explain that we had no choice but to terminate him with extreme prejudice as taking him into custody and placing him at Gitmo has been nixed by the president's liberal supporters.
So now WE are issuing fatwahs?

Perhaps WikiLeaks is obliged to engage in something akin to investigative journalism because the mainstream news media have abdicated their constitutional mandate to inform the democratic citizenry of this country what its supposedly civilian-controlled military is doing.  The truth is only dangerous to a government if what that government is doing is illegal and/or immoral.

“Critics contend that the video was misleading because it did not make clear that the attacks took place amid clashes in the neighborhood and that one of the men was carrying a rocket-propelled grenade.”

What rocket-propelled grenade?

There are absolutely no AK-47’s held or carried or shouldered or aimed or fired in the WikiLeak video. At the 3:39 to about 4:02 (of the edited 17-minute video) the two men most suspected of appearing-to-be-armed momentarily stand under a pole. It is clear the heavier-set man in the stripped shirt was not carrying a weapon. It was merely a cloth or towel or rag of some sort. He momentarily turns from the camera and appears “empty-handed” at about the 4:00 minute mark. With the poor resolution/poor quality of the video, it is impossible to say what the other man was carrying. Any “expert” who says it WAS an RPG lacks any real credibility. By the way the man holds and carries and handles the object – and the momentary base glint -- the object is much more likely to have been a camera tripod or some relatively lightweight accessory to the photo-shoot. By the motioning of his arm in the direction of where the reporters were, it appears they were merely attempting to determine the logistics of their camera shots.

It is clear from the recent “collateral murder execution” of 5 Afghans (3 who were women, 2 who were pregnant) and the blatant, extensive, ongoing US-command cover-up … that it would not be hard to imagine the so-called weapons found after that WikiLeaked Baghdad “collateral murder incident” were just another routine ad hoc invention to hide collateral and war crime body counts.

Remember "The Bourne Ultimatum"? There was a program of assassinations of US citizens in the movie. It was so bad it had to be kept secret from the politicians; it was illegal; and it caused a scandal and prosecutions when it came out. How naive! In reality it's now just openly declared by our government that it will murder US citizens without even charging them with a crime, let alone giving them a trial.

I never thought I'd say this, bit I'm glad that at least the second amendment is being interpreted expansively - we may well need it to defend ourselves.

Official approval. As opposed to the covert action that typically surrounds the killing of an American by our governme...
Nevermind.
The sacred man begins as citizen.

Put aside, for the moment whether Mr. Awlaki deserves his fate. Look at the bigger picture. We pride ourselves as being a country of laws. Doesn’t an American Citizen deserve his day in court: A chance to face his accusers and answer the charges against him, and then have a life or death sentence decided by a jury of his peers?

If the Executive Branch, on its own and for its own reasons, can kill a citizen, then NONE OF US ARE SAFE.
Good man. I hope he stays safe.

I thought assassination of individuals (as opposed to killing in the context of military actions) was against longstanding US policy (not that it didn't happen, just that it was officially verboten).

I wonder what the motivation is for revealing that this person is a target?
Increase credibility with a US audience?
Cause those who might shelter him to think twice?
Give us standing in some other ongoing negotiation?
I remember "wanted" lists, such as GW's deck of playing cards, but I do not recall the publication of any hit lists. Aren't we meant to get a conviction in court, with a sentence of death, before we go around executing people who are not actually (ie: literally) pointing guns at someone?

I don't like this guy, but I really don't approve of this, and the manner of this public announcement has the ring of grandstanding at the expense of someone's life. Even the Israelis don't announce in advance whom they're going to whack, so far as I know.

Thank you, WikiLeaks, for showing and telling the truth. Of course, when you watch the video your opinion about what happened will be totally biased by your opinion about the war prior to seeing it. From my point of view, this was outright murder, plain and simple. These guys were more than eager to play their little video game and shoot human beings dead. "C'mon already! I can't wait. Let me shoot. Let me shoot." My God, the Iraqis were standing on the ground gathering together to talk to one another and were simply gunned down. Then when another vehicle came to the aid of the survivors (children?), out came the call. Engage! (Shoot! Kill!) HEROES???
I'm in total agreement with the Obama administration. God bless America and death to all her enemies, foreign and domestic.
So too will die the US Constitution and ultimately the American empire.
Good.

Extra-judicial murders used to be considered illegal and unacceptable under our laws. And so it was with torture, government kidnapping (otherwise known as "extreme rendition" and the whole range of customary police-state behaviors which have become commonplace now in America.
Anwar al-Awlaki may be a dangerous and unsavory person, operating in his lair far away. But like his cohort bin Laden, it appears he's being very successful in dismantling what once was America's purported claim to being a land where the law was supreme, etc. Of course with the current Supreme Court deciding what is the law, perhaps its best we shed this charade once and for all.

www.cinemaelectronica.wordpress.com
www.jonjost.wordpress.com

It would have been so much more effective if WikiLeaks simply posted the video without the accompanying biased commentary. WikiLeaks had the resourcefulness to secure the video, but not the professional discipline to let the images do the talking. That lack of journalistic discipline will cause anything WikiMedia posts to be viewed with some degree of suspicion. It will also hurt possible donations. Too bad, because no matter where you came out on the video, it raised some important questions about war, what happens to people (on both sides) during war, and what constitutes "right action" during combat. All very important issues that Fox, MSNBC and CNN don;t seem to raise.
